channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump’s Rift With Europe Is Clear. Europe Must Decide What to Do About It.
item.description: After President Trump aired his disdain for Europe, its leaders will gather in Brussels Thursday to take stock of what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Rutte, the NATO secretary-general, meeting with President Trump in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: China Wins as Trump Cedes Leadership of the Global Economy
item.description: The president used a keynote speech at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland to renounce the last vestiges of the liberal democratic order.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: “Everybody took advantage of the United States,” President Trump told an audience at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Drops Tariff Threats Over Greenland After Meeting With NATO Chief
item.description: President Trump’s announcement appeared to draw the United States back from the possibility of military and economic conflict with American allies over Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes, Jim Tankersley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Hours after his address to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, President Trump said he had reached a framework agreement with the leader of NATO over the future of Greenland.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Would Have Global Scope but One Man in Charge
item.description: The initiative is the latest example of the president dismantling the post-World War II international system and building a new one, with himself at the center.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel, Saudi Arabia and other nations have said they would join President Trump’s proposed “Board of Peace,” but France, Norway and Sweden have said no.

item.title: Cuban Detainee in El Paso ICE Facility Died by Homicide, Autopsy Shows
item.description: The report from the county medical examiner said the detainee, Geraldo Lunas Campos, was asphyxiated and restrained by law enforcement. Federal officials described his death as a suicide.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Camp East Montana, a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention facility at Fort Bliss in El Paso.

item.title: Court Removes Restrictions on ICE’s Use of Pepper Spray, for Now
item.description: The Eighth Circuit granted the Trump administration’s request to block, for the moment, a lower court’s injunction limiting how federal agents interact with protesters in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal officers clashed with protesters after Renee Good was shot and killed in Minneapolis earlier this month.

item.title: Former Uvalde Officer Adrian Gonzales Found Not Guilty of Endangering Children in Mass Shooting
item.description: Adrian Gonzales had faced 29 charges for his actions in the 2022 shooting, in which 19 children were killed by a gunman at Robb Elementary School in Texas.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Memorials honoring the victims of the Robb Elementary school shooting in Uvalde, Texas.

item.title: Widespread Winter Storm Is Forecast to Bring Heavy Snow to Central and Eastern US
item.description: People across a large section of the central and eastern United States are facing predictions of heavy snow and ice starting Friday.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Snow Maps and More: Everything You Could Want to Know About This Winter Storm
item.description: Here’s a look at the latest forecasts, and how to prepare.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Erin McCann
item.media:credit: Kiichiro Sato/Associated Press
item.media:description: Parts of the Great Lakes and Upper Midwest were under extreme cold warnings on Wednesday.

item.title: FCC Targets Colbert and Kimmel in New Crackdown on Late-Night TV
item.description: The F.C.C. said it planned to enforce long-dormant rules on appearances by political candidates on network talk shows.
item.dc:creator: Jim Rutenberg
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brendan Carr, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

item.title: RFK Jr., Kicking Off National Tour, Says He’s Not Running for President
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. rallied supporters at the Pennsylvania State Capitol, where he promoted his new dietary guidelines.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. held a rally on Wednesday at the Pennsylvania State Capitol to mark the start of a national “Take Back Your Health” tour.

item.title: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Reject Trump’s Attempt to Immediately Fire a Fed Governor
item.description: During arguments, key justices appeared concerned that the president’s efforts to oust Lisa Cook could imperil the central bank’s independence.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Supreme Court is expected to rule on Lisa Cook’s case in the coming weeks or months.

item.title: Supreme Court Hearing Reveals Unease Over Threats to Fed Independence
item.description: As the justices weighed the consequences of allowing President Trump to fire a Federal Reserve official, the president reprised his pressure campaign on the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lisa D. Cook, a Federal Reserve governor whom President Trump tried to fire last year over allegations of mortgage fraud.

item.title: Iran’s Protests Have Been Completely Squashed, Government Says
item.description: After a crackdown that killed thousands, Iran’s prosecutor general said on Wednesday that “the sedition is over now,” vowing to punish those responsible for the protests.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph taken during a tour for international news media shows a tax office that was burned during protests, on Wednesday in Tehran.

item.title: At Yosemite National Park, Staffing Cuts Mean Visitors Have Gone Wild
item.description: After the Trump administration’s cuts, workers at the national park are spread too thin to stop people from littering, flying drones and cliff-diving.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla and Angus Morton
item.media:credit: Angus Morton for The New York Times

item.title: Rahm Emanuel Calls for Age Limit of 75 for President, Congress and Judges
item.description: The former Chicago mayor, who is trying to shape the Democratic Party’s future and might run for president, said that “across all three branches of government, 75 years — you’re out.”
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rahm Emanuel is one of the prominent Democrats who have been most active in trying to guide the party’s direction.

item.title: Michelle Obama and Gretchen Whitmer Disagree on America’s Readiness for a Female President
item.description: As Mrs. Obama defended her remarks from November that the country wasn’t ready for a woman as president, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan offered a different view.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert/Associated Press
item.media:description: Michelle Obama in November. In a new interview, she said she could eventually foresee a woman as president, but asked: “Are we ready now? I don’t know. Prove us wrong. I would love that.”

item.title: Michele Tafoya Announces Senate Run in Minnesota
item.description: Ms. Tafoya, once a sideline reporter for N.F.L. games, has more recently turned her focus to Republican politics. She is seeking an open seat now held by a Democrat.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Michael Ainsworth/Associated Press
item.media:description: Michele Tafoya joins a fledgling Republican primary field in the race to replace Senator Tina Smith, a Democrat who is retiring.

item.title: Judge Rules for Democrats in Push to Redraw N.Y.C. House District
item.description: The ruling, which is expected to be appealed, allows the state to change the boundary lines of a district held by a Staten Island Republican since 2021.
item.dc:creator: Grace Ashford and Benjamin Oreskes
item.media:credit: Erik McGregor/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The only Republican district in New York City, represented by Nicole Malliotakis of Staten Island, would be redrawn under the court ruling.

item.title: Job Applicants Sue A.I. Recruitment Tool Company
item.description: A recently filed lawsuit claims the ratings assigned by A.I. screening software are similar to those of a credit agency and should be subject to the same laws.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Erin Kistler at her Los Angeles home.

item.title: Months After Daniel Naroditsky’s Death, the Chess World Remains Divided
item.description: The death of Daniel Naroditsky exposed the conflicts between the game’s traditional wing and its many online stars.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times

item.title: Hollywood’s Woke Era Is Over. Now It’s Turning the Culture War Into Camp.
item.description: The industry seemed penned in by our political debates — until it started channeling them into wild caricatures and frothy drama.
item.dc:creator: Casey Michael Henry

item.title: An Unhinged President on the Magic Mountain
item.description: Trump’s Davos speech could have been ghostwritten by Mario Puzo.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Jonathan Ernst/Reuters

item.title: My Rohingya People Are Running Out of Time
item.description: Genocide hearings in The Hague offer a ray of hope for the Rohingya, but aid cuts are worsening a humanitarian crisis in refugee camps.
item.dc:creator: Lucky Karim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times

item.title: House Panel Votes to Hold Clintons in Contempt in Epstein Inquiry
item.description: The votes by the Oversight panel were bipartisan, though many Democrats said the charges were extreme given Bill and Hillary Clinton’s willingness to answer questions.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representatives James R. Comer, right, Republican of Kentucky and the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, and Robert Garcia of California, its ranking Democrat, during Wednesday’s session.

item.title: Heart Disease and Stroke Still Leading Causes of Death in U.S.
item.description: Deaths from both causes are down, but they still eclipse all other causes, according to new statistics.
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times

item.title: Parents Sue Residential Home Over Abuse of Their Autistic Son
item.description: Anil and Shalini Babbar said they would not have known about the abuse their teenager was enduring at the home in upstate New York if a whistle-blower had not sent footage of an assault.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Anil and Shalini Babbar’s son was diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder after his stay at the Anderson Center for Autism, according to their lawsuit.

item.title: Austin Thompson Pleads Guilty in North Carolina Shooting That Left 5 Dead
item.description: It is highly uncommon for mass shooters to plead guilty in a country where such attacks seem all too frequent. The man’s lawyers said he wanted to spare the community from further trauma.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Veasey Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at the Hedingham Golf Club in Raleigh, N.C., in 2022, honoring the slain victims. The shooter pleaded guilty on Wednesday to all the charges against him.
